Tyler]]<br>([[House of Representatives of Liberia|Speaker]]) |founded = 1984 |slogan = One Nation, One People, With Liberty And Justice For All |ideology = [[Economic liberalism]],<br>[[Liberal democracy]],<br>[[Centrism]] |international = [[International Democrat Union]] |affiliation1_title = Continental affiliation |affiliation1 = [[Democrat Union of Africa]] |colours = Green and maroon |seats1_title = [[Senate of Liberia|Seats in the Senate]] |seats1 = {{Infobox political party/seats|10|30|hex=#008000}} |seats2_title = [[House of Representatives of Liberia|Seats in the House]] |seats2 = {{Infobox political party/seats|25|73|hex=#008000}} |seats3_title = [[Pan African Parliament]] |seats3 = {{Infobox political party/seats|2|5|hex=#008000}} |website = |country = Liberia }} The '''Unity Party''' (UP) is a [[List of political parties in Liberia|political party]] in [[Liberia]] that was started in 1984 by [[Edward Kesselly|Edward B. Kesselly]], also its first standard bearer. Officially founded at [[Buchanan, Liberia|Buchanan]] in [[Grand Bassa County]], the party was established on 27 July 1985.<ref>"UP To Do Formal Launching Tomorrow". <nowiki>[Monrovia]</nowiki> ''SunTimes'', 1985-07-26: 1/13.</ref> The Unity Party participated in the [[Liberian general election, 1985|first elections]] after the [[People's Redemption Council|1980 coup]], running against then-President [[Samuel Doe]] in October 1985. The Party has remained active in Liberian politics since, and is now the ruling party in the Republic. In the previous [[Liberia elections, 1997|elections]] held on 19 July 1997, the UP presidential candidate [[Ellen Johnson Sirleaf]] won 9.58% of the vote. The party won 7 of 64 seats in the [[House of Representatives of Liberia|House of Representatives]] and 3 of 26 in the [[Senate of Liberia|Senate]]. While international observers deemed the polls administratively free and transparent, they noted that it had taken place in an atmosphere of intimidation because most voters believed that former rebel leader and [[National Patriotic Party]] (NPP) candidate [[Charles G. Taylor|Charles Taylor]] would return to [[First Liberian Civil War|war]] if defeated. Unity Party's candidate [[Ellen Johnson Sirleaf]] won the [[Liberia elections, 2005|2005 presidential elections]], besting [[George Weah]] of the [[Congress for Democratic Change]] (CDC) in a [[Two-round system|run-off]]. The party also won 3 seats in the [[Senate of Liberia|Senate]] and 8 in the [[House of Representatives of Liberia|House of Representatives]].
